"unions generate surplus income"; WOW, you need to repeat Economics 101a. Unions drive up wages so companies buy from less expensive sources like China. AT&T made most of their equipment when I was a kid. I still have a crank telephone they made. Now they buy most of their equipment from China and Japan.

"Do they typically subtract income tax after reporting earnings?" No; income tax is deducted (or added) before earnings per share is calculated. It is recorded on a cash basis so it screws up the final figure.

My grandson who is in the Army tells me that it is almost impossible to find an Obama supporter in his battalion. I guess they were missed in your poll. I guess Obama doesn't believe your poll either, or he wouldn't try to make it more difficult for military from Ohio to vote.

Message.Title: T looks dead for now...
Message.Msg: ...big market days aren't moving this stock anymore at all. The nice run up looks to be over. I'm in for the long haul so I'll hold but I wouldn't put any new $$ in T right now. Seems certain you'll be able to get a much better price in near future.

>>>I guess they were missed in your poll. Definitely possible, especially if they are stationed overseas. The military doesn't really make soldiers available for public opinion polls and the military discourages soldiers from expressing political positions. So always take these polls with a grain of salt. Pollster tend to come at the opinion of military personnel from different angles, including polls of military families and recent vets. When these two things converge, you can kind of triangulate military positions. Throw in the fundraising edge from military personnel going to Obama, and you get confirmation. The issue seems to be dissatisfaction with Republican adventurism. Ron Paul had the edge in the primaries. Once he was out, military support went to Obama. And why not? His foreign policy has been aggressive, subtle and effective but not warmongering. And the military is predominantly made up of young Americans. Throw in the sequestration debacle and why would anyone in the military support Republicans? >>>he wouldn't try to make it more difficult for military from Ohio to vote. So you've said. I'll throw that claim in with his secret commie father.

It is probably a good time to sell covered calls. The chart indicates that a drop in price should occur soon. Slow Stochastic is at 83 and headed down. Selling usually starts when the slow stochastic crosses below 80. The fast Stochastic crossed 80 last Wednesday and is already down to 35. http://finance.yahoo.com/echarts?s=t#symbol=t;range=ytd;compare=;indicator=dividend+sma%2820%29+bollinger+volume+stochasticslow;charttype=candlestick;crosshair=on;ohlcvalues=1;logscale=off;source=undefined;

Message.Msg: Purchased Sept $40 puts to protect my gains very cheap today

They do generate disposable income to drive consumption. It's pretty simple. If AT&T wants to charge $150+ a month for a wireless and data plan, you need consumers able to pay that much. Employers may be able to move to China and pay their workers next to nothing, but those workers cannot afford $150+ a month wireless plans. Or iphones. Or F150s. At some point something gives, and I think it has happened. You need a balance between wages and profits and unions help to maintain that balance.

Message.Title: Re: re Obama denies military
Message.Msg: ... Jon - Okay, you lowlife, dipstick...Would you for once acknowledge when you're caught trying to spread bogus propaganda. You are a flat out lying tool of the Tea Party. And you should be ashamed of yourself…but your kind, and what you represent, apparently has no shame, morals or principles. Only two hours ago, you posted the following: It was reported - this group ("Virginia Participation Center") sent 10 mil. mailings in 10 mos. - yep, that's the report. It was also reported that 700 "Voter Fraud" complaints were filed on these mailings. Only problem is that the following was posted yesterday VirginiaWatchdog. org “VA: Elections Board Not to Probe Group’s Voter Registration Drive August 6th, Carten Cordell ALEXANDRIA — The Voter Participation Center, a voter advocacy group, claimed victory Monday, after the Virginia Board of Elections declined to investigate allegations that the group’s registration drive violated state law. The presidential campaign for presumptive GOP nominee Mitt Romney asked the state board to look into whether the Washington, D.C.-based group committed voter fraud by using magazine subscription lists to mail registration forms to children, dead people and household pets, as first reported in the Richmond Times-Dispatch. After the state board declined to investigate, the Voter Participation Center posted a news release on its website, saying: “This is a win for the citizens of Virginia who want to participate in the democratic process and an affirmation that the VPC program is legal, helpful and essential.” - end So you castigate grass roots political initiatives to get citizens involved in the political process, while you’re secretly working to deny them those rights. It’s just another pernicious attempt to limit the right of ALL Americans to vote, with sleezeballs like you trying to defend modern day Jim Crow efforts at partisan manipulation of those rights.

It seems to me the best way to maintain a balance between wages and profit would be to pay half of the wages in shares of stock. Employees could then become owners of the company or they could sell their shares and waste the proceeds like regular Americans do.

I see no reason that both of these statements can't be true. "It was reported - this group ("Virginia Participation Center") sent 10 mil. mailings in 10 mos. - yep, that's the report. It was also reported that 700 "Voter Fraud" complaints were filed on these mailings. Only problem is that the following was posted yesterday VirginiaWatchdog. org “VA: Elections Board Not to Probe Group’s Voter Registration Drive" What is YOUR problem Echo?

Message.Title: the rapidly approaching death of the middle class
Message.Msg: There is a real disturbing trend going on in America today, Prosperous companies demanding major givebacks of their workers. This is going to end with with all of our children working for Walmart (min wage and no benefits) if people don't wise up and start supporting each other.. 22,000 AT&T workers are on strike right now because they don't want their pensions robbed and their healthcare gutted. The company makes billions in profit and the CEO's salary is 25 million dollars a year. Caterpillar is a prosperous company, The stock is surging --- but that does not seem to stop the corporate suits from demanding major givebacks of the employees. Pay freezes, pension freezes, it's all fair game. The Caterpillar employees are on strike right now rather than sell future generations down the river. There was just a one month lockout at Con Edison, another prosperous company, where the 11 million dollar a year CEO locked out 8500 employees and immediately canceled their health insurance! Their stock was at an all time high but the executives still wanted givebacks related to pensions, healthcare, and other things.. Governor Cuomo had to step into the negotiations to get them back to work. Verizon is reportedly very close to locking out it's 45,000 employees.The company is a money making machine. The top 5 executives have been paid 350 million dollars over the past 5 years yet they are demanding everything under the sun back from the employees. Pensions, healthcare, sicktime, overtime etc.... And they are sending lots of American jobs to India and the Philippines. Seems to me profitable corporations are doing their best to kill the American middle class even as they enjoy tax breaks and get favorable legislation from the politicians that are supposed to be representing "the people". A disgrace.

Actually, I took that course- and just a few others...more math, physics, and computer science than business or economics, though. I don't regret my choices. Look...there are two spirals possible- a growth spiral, and a death spiral. We are in the latter. Unions drive the former. At any period during which unions were prevalent, the economy was robust. During periods where they were not, you had "robber barons"- and general poverty. I'm not here to educate you. If you haven't already grasped reality, your acumen in other venues is worthless.

I'd go for that- then you'd have a genuine profit sharing plan, and a more direct motivation to serve customers. In addition to that, I'd want strong clawback provisions for both the CEO and the BOD- because a golden parachute without repercussions assures an ethical bankruptcy which inevitably chooses short term profit over long term solvency.

I doubt we'll see a settlement soon in D9- unless it's for a lawsuit. Three people in two different locations were run over by company drivers today- one remains in the hospital; two others suffered less serious injuries and were examined, treated, and released. Reality has a way of prevailing over even the most oft written lies- but sadly, the only ink the truth has available is usually blood.

Topic.Title: the rapidly approaching death of the middle class

Message.Msg: I agree- but there's a reason avarice is a deadly sin: it's a force that utterly destroys love, charity, humility, and a plethora of other virtues. Hence comes the old saw: "Easier a camel through the eye of a needle than a rich man through the gates of heaven."
Hey echo...quit beating that dead horse! You can't teach him anything, it annoys the maggots, and you might get splattered.
It is equally nice to see your spin still reflects your disability.....without some stars to steer by (some towards, some from)- one could remain lost forever.

A union leaders first priority is to bargain the best contract possible for their membership and Cohen may be doing just that.In an environment where the economy is on the verge of recession and unemployement is at 8.3% it's not a good time to strike.The tenative agreement in the other districts has a decent wage increase and it's just a fact of life these days everyone will share the healthcare cost.The folks in California need only look as far as the many cities over there that have filed bankruptcy to see pie in the sky contracts are not viable in this economic enviroment.
